item.title: A key question for the Fed will be whether the economy is weakening or whether a recent slowdown in job growth reflects temporary factors
item.description: A key question for the Fed will be whether the economy is weakening or whether a recent slowdown in job growth reflects temporary factors.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: U.S. Factory Activity Continues to Contract
item.description: The Institute for Supply Management said its purchasing managers’ index of manufacturing activity contracted to 48 in July from 49 in June.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.S. job growth slowed in July, a signal that pockets of weakness that had been marring the labor market are starting to take hold
item.description: July’s report ​suggests that pockets of weakness in the labor market are starting to take hold. The unemployment rate rose slightly to 4.2%.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Businesses Continue to Face Uncertainty After Latest U.S. Tariff Blitz, ICC Says
item.description: Businesses around the world are still seeking clarity on the barriers they will face as exporters to the U.S., with many pausing big decisions on investment and hiring, according to the deputy head of the International Chamber of Commerce.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Holds Steady at Target, Leaving ECB in ‘Good Place’
item.description: Consumer prices in July were 2.0% higher than the same month of last year, matching the inflation rate of June.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump promised Africa that trade would replace aid, but in one of the world’s poorest countries his administration is slashing both
item.description: President Trump promised Africa that trade would replace aid, but in one of the world’s poorest countries his administration is slashing both.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: President Trump’s tariff rollout has taken numerous twists and turns since launching earlier this year. Here’s a roundup of where things stand.
item.description: A roundup of where things stand with tariffs on key U.S. trade partners and sectors.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham

item.title: South Korea’s Exports Accelerate, Fueled by Chip Demand
item.description: Export growth was stronger than expected in July, driven by strong demand for high-performance computing chips amid an AI boom.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: U.S.-Canada Trade Talks Dealing With Aluminum-Tariff Levels, Bessent Says
item.description: The Treasury secretary’s comments signaled possible relief for Canada’s aluminum sector.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Someone has to pay the skyrocketing tariffs the U.S. is collecting on imports—and companies say some of the burden will fall on consumers
item.description: Someone has to pay the skyrocketing levies the U.S. is collecting on imports—and companies say some of the burden will fall on consumers.
item.dc:creator: Anthony DeBarros

item.title: South Africa’s central bank cut its main repo rate by a quarter percentage point as inflation remains low in the midst of continuing global uncertainty
item.description: The central bank cut its main repo rate by a quarter percentage point as inflation remains low in the midst of continuing global uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Four charts show how the condo market is floundering
item.description: More condos are on the market, and units are taking longer to sell.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: Bank of Japan Raises Price Forecasts, Fueling Rate-Hike Hopes
item.description: The central bank held its overnight call rate target steady at 0.5%, where it has remained since its last hike in January.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Fed Chair Jerome Powell is keeping his options wide open for the September meeting, promising little while ruling out nothing
item.description: Fed chair Jerome Powell is keeping his options wide open for the September meeting, promising little while ruling out nothing.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Two Fed officials dissented the central bank’s decision to hold rates steady
item.description: Dissents highlight a fraying consensus among policymakers, who are debating the effects that tariffs will have on the economy and inflation
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: A look at the policymakers who get an equal say on each Federal Reserve interest-rate decision
item.description: Jerome Powell has been President Trump’s No. 1 target as Trump demands lower interest rates, but other policymakers are also part of each rate decision.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Pending Home Sales Fell Unexpectedly in June
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. unexpectedly declined in June, as high prices and mortgage rates persist.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Consumer-Confidence Survey Improved in July
item.description: The Conference Board’s consumer-confidence index climbed to 97.2, from 95.2 in June. But American consumers’ economic mood remained clouded by tariff and labor market concerns.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Canada Housing Market Braces for Extended Pricing Slump
item.description: Home buyers and builders in Canada are in retreat, adding to the woes of an economy struggling under the weight of President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Capital Account: Trump has hit his tariff goals, for now. But these deals don’t yet represent a new trade order
item.description: The tariff deals are sort of a way station, more fragile and with less legitimacy than the system they have supplanted.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Contracts as U.S. Front-Running Cools
item.description: A surge in exports to the U.S. which led Ireland to far outstrip the growth rates of other rich economies waned in the three months through June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Individual home buyers are largely locked out of the residential housing market, leaving room for investors
item.description: High interest rates and prices are deterring individual buyers, leaving an opening for firms to snap up single-family properties.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Capital Account: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans
item.description: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate Again as Economy Slows
item.description: Friday marked the second-straight time the Bank of Russia cut its interest rate after it lowered borrowing costs in early June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Retailers Get Summer Boost as Drinks Sales Soar
item.description: Retail sales were 0.9% higher on month in June, with alcoholic and nonalcoholic drinks among the products which saw higher sales.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Consumers Are Feeling Gloomier Amid Foundering Economy, Rising Prices
item.description: U.K. consumer sentiment worsened as the country faces an unhappy combination of weak growth and still-high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Global Economies Show Resilience Despite Tariff Fears, Surveys Show
item.description: The U.S. economy and its peers in Europe and Asia continued to show resilience in the face of high levels of uncertainty about the future of trade and international relations, although export orders weakened.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Fewer U.S. Jobless Claims Were Filed Last Week
item.description: U.S. initial jobless claims declined last week, according to the Department of Labor, extending a stretch of evidence that layoffs have remained constrained.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Consumer Confidence Hit by Economic Uncertainty
item.description: Sentiment continued to worsen as growing economic uncertainty encouraged shoppers to save rather than spend, according to a monthly survey.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Eurozone Consumers’ Mood Improves a Little
item.description: Consumers in the eurozone are a little less gloomy as inflation stabilizes, despite global economic uncertainty, a recent monthly survey showed.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Home prices rose to a new high in June while the crucial spring sales season fizzled
item.description: The key spring-selling season failed to deliver, making a housing-market recovery unlikely this year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined to 221,000 last week, the Labor Department said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Climb in Australian Jobless Rate Opens Door to Rate Cut
item.description: Australia’s unemployment rate rose unexpectedly in June, significantly boosting the case for an interest-rate cut in August.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Leading Economies Must Work Together to Fix Imbalances, or Face Instability, Says BOE’s Bailey
item.description: The U.S., China and other leading economies should work together to agree on a set of national policies that will help narrow the large imbalances that now threaten the global trade system, the Bank of England governor said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The number of Americans who newly filed for unemployment benefits declined last week, the Labor Department said, although the report suggested that the size of the unemployed population continued to grow in June.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. job growth looked solid in June, but the headline number hides a stark reality: Many private employers aren’t hiring anymore.
item.description: The U.S. economy added 147,000 jobs in June, but nearly half were in government.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber
